posts.name: Guy Levy
posts.cooked:
What solutions do teams implement to address common issues with bearing such as slipping out or “eating through” extrusions, and how effective have these solutions been in improving the reliability and durability of your robot’s mechanisms? My team uses something that we call “Bearing Housing” which is a ring that holds the bearing from its so-called “outer side” and prevents it from slipping out. I’ve seen teams like Robowanglers 148 and Barker Redbacks 4613 that used bolts to hold the bearing in place on some of their past robots, but I would love to know what are some of the other solutions that you guys use.

DSC_0005 - Copy 1421×871 200 KB

DSC_0005 - Copy 1421×871 200 KB

DSC_0005 - Copy 1421×871 200 KB

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: We make our robot to have the bearings be press fit, so they don’t fall out, but for the most part everything we do has the shaft and the bearings constrained through either bolts tapped into the shaft or shaft collars or similar

usually screws or press fit. Depending on the application we’ll make something similar to this:

Need a strong, secure way to retain your 1.125 inch OD bearings? Does your bearing need a hat? Then do we have the product for you! Quickly and easily ensure your bearings are retained. Works especially well in conjunction with materials like...

If I need a bearing in a thin wall material, I just layer some material in that specific area.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
In an effort to standardize parts this year, we created some Onshape configurable parts. For almost all bearings we used this assembly. (It’s configurable, so there are several options depending on what is needed).

On our polycarbonate intake, we were able to still lose the bearings with a big hits. For State/Worlds we switched to these from TTB, and they worked extremely well for us.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.cooked: Flanges on the inside can help keep the bearing in if you have a full shaft. Screws can also be placed on the outside if the design didn’t originally use a retaining plate.

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:

posts.name: John Keyzer
posts.cooked:
We tap the end of the shaft and use a washer (blue part) that is smaller than the  diameter of the inner race  so that it can spin, then use a screw. This has to be the case on both sides so that the shaft is captured. image 1194×800 141 KB

image 1194×800 141 KB

image 1194×800 141 KB

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
John_Keyzer:

This has to be the case on both sides so that the shaft is captured.

It also has to be a rigid mechanism. I’ve seen this method used on polycarb intakes, which flex when hit causing the bearings to pop out, even though it “seems” fully constrained when in a static setting while assembling/repairing.

posts.name: Jeffrey Lewis
posts.cooked:
In that case, we also tap 4 holes into the polycarb real close to the bearing holes so that when we thread screws into those holes, their heads overlap with the outer race/flange of the bearings to hold them in.

The additional holes around the bearing holes don’t seem to weaken the polycarb too much as long as there’s enough extra in that area to begin with.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Another solution (which is fast to apply at competition) is to just toss a 2 piece shaft collar on the other side of the polycarbonate plate. This constrains the bearing (via the shaft) with a washer/bolt on one side of the plate and the collar on the other. Quick and dirty.

I have wanted to make mini gimbals (1 &2 degrees of freedom) to support floppy intakes and shafts. With summer cad/mfg  plans probably being messed up this year this is a nice small project I could take on pretty easily.

posts.name: Ezriel Nagaokar
posts.cooked:
We have the same thing, we have put shaft collar image 1452×1670 676 KB

posts.name: Jeffrey Lewis
posts.cooked: To be clear, the screws I talked about are designed into the mechanisms from the start for bearing retention so we shouldn’t ever have to deal with bearings popping out at competition. (Emphasis on shouldn’t )
we usually just drill a few holes around the edge of the bearing flange (or have it designed with them already there) and rivet it in place.
